taglines: [u'First comes love. Then comes the interrogation.', u'No pressure.', u"He finally met the girl of his dreams. Too bad her dad's a nightmare."]
trivia: [u'The MPAA would not allow the name "Focker" unless the filmmakers could find an actual person with that surname.', u'Robert De Niro wanted "Mr. Jinx" to appear in more scenes than he was supposed to because De Niro liked the cat so much. Apparently, De Niro would also play with the cat between filming scenes.', u'At one time, Jim Carrey was slated to star as the lead and even contributed jokes to the screenplay, such as the main character being named "Focker."', u'The role of Pam Byrnes was initially given to Naomi Watts. She ultimately lost the role to Teri Polo because the filmmakers did not think she was "sexy" enough.', u'Christopher Walken was the second choice to play Jack Byrnes.', u"This is the only film in the series in which Pam's sister, Deborah Byrnes, appears onscreen, though she is frequently mentioned in all of the films. Nicole DeHuff, the actress who played her, died in 2005.", u'Jack\'s Thai is extremely poor and he is constantly repeating the word "what," making it seem like it is a longer conversation than it is. Thais applauded Robert De Niro\'s effort, however.', u'According to the DVD commentary, the car chase scene was originally meant to be a spoof of Ronin (1998). When the filmmakers got to the location, they saw how quickly the lights changed, realized it would be a funnier joke, and rewrote the scene (the lights really did change from green to red as fast as they are shown in the movie).', u"Greg's MCAT scores are (out of 15): 14 Verbal reasoning, 13 Physical Sciences, 15 Biological Sciences, and an R on the Writing Sample (very high).", u'According to Teri Polo, in the scene where she and Ben Stiller are making out on her bed and he fondles her breast, she stuffed cookies into her bra as a gag.', u'Anthony Hopkins was considered for the role of Jack Byrnes.', u"Pam calls Gaylord's parents in Detroit, Michigan. However, in the sequel, they live in Florida. When the Byrnes first arrive to the Fockers' home in the sequel, Greg's dad states that they moved from Detroit.", u"When Jack first questions Greg about the circle of trust, he says that nineteen months in a Vietnamese prison made him a patient man. This is a reference to The Deer Hunter (1978), where Robert De Niro's character spends time in a Vietnamese POW (prisoner of war) prison.", u'The home video footage of Teri Polo during the opening credits was filmed by her ex-husband Anthony Moore.', u'Writer Jerry Stahl, whom Ben Stiller portrayed in Permanent Midnight (1998), co-wrote the "cat milking" scene in this movie.', u'Owen Wilson brought a lot of his own ideas to the film and improvised many of his lines.', u'When Greg says grace at the dinner table. It is actually the song "Day By Day", from the award winning musical Godspell.', u'Julia Stiles auditioned for the part of Pam, but dropped out due to filming 10 Things I Hate About You (1999).', u'Ben Stiller flew out to Los Angeles to propose to Christine Taylor while shooting the film. She thought he was still in New York, and he surprised her at home with a path of candles and rose petals.', u'The film inspired a cat toilet-training product called "Litter Kwitter," which sold over 750,000 units.', u"Mr. Jinx is a Himalayan cat, a difficult breed to train. The trainers begged Jay Roach to choose another kind of cat, but he really liked the Himalayan's look.", u'Ben Stiller hated his clothes in the film. Director Jay Roach said it was all part of the plan to keep Stiller as uncomfortable as Greg.', u"John Hamburg, Ben Stiller's preferred screenwriter, did an uncredited rewrite during production.", u'Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor did an uncredited last script draft before shooting.', u'Robert De Niro took this role as part of his new focus on comedy. He had previously just done Analyze This (1999).', u'Director Jay Roach wanted the whole movie to feel like an "anxiety dream" for Greg.', u'Since cats are very temperamental, the filmmakers always had a back-up cat on set in case one would not cooperate.', u'The idea to use a lie detector test came from Robert De Niro while he was researching a role. He read up on polygraphs and presented his findings to director Jay Roach at a pre-shoot dinner. "At that point, there was no lie detector scene in the script," Roach told Entertainment Weekly. "But after hearing all this, I thought, \'Oh, this has to be in our movie.\' Now it\'s become the central image of all the ads, the trailers, everything." Jack Byrnes being ex-CIA was always part of his characters since the beginning, however.', u"Jack's knowledge of the NATO standard phonetic alphabet (Foxtrot, Oscar, Charlie, Kilo, Echo, Romeo, aka Focker) is all accurate.", u"It was Ben Stiller's idea to make Greg a male nurse.", u'Most of the movie was filmed without deciding how to say "Focker," so they had to go back and re-record it.', u"Writer Jim Herzfeld's influence for Greg was Benjamin Braddock in The Graduate (1967). Herzfeld used Benjamin to write a main character who was completely misunderstood.", u"Greg's airplane rant was cut from the version shown on planes.", u'The costume designer put Jack in soft sweaters to contrast the tough guy-type Robert De Niro usually plays.', u"When Ben Stiller came on board, the script was retooled. Originally, it had been written for Jim Carrey so it contained more physical, knockabout comedy. Stiller's style is less physical so this element in the script was rewritten.", u'Director Jay Roach was terrified to direct Meet the Parents (2000) and was nervous about attempting to sell the project to both Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller. Stiller thought Roach was only pretending to be nervous. Roach swears he was not. "I don\'t think it was strategy," Roach told Entertainment Weekly. "I wanted them to know I was terrified. I\'m really bad at faking."', u'Ever the Method actor, Robert De Niro chose to keep his distance from Ben Stiller during the shoot to help him maintain an aloofness between the two men.', u'The scenes at the "Surf and Turf" restaurant were filmed at a Port Washington, NY restaurant called "Louie\'s." The car racing scenes between Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro were also filmed in downtown Port Washington. Also, the scene where Stiller and De Niro go shopping is in Port Washington at Salem Drugs.', u"Westchester County Regional Airport in New York state was used to portray Chicago's O'Hare International Airport and New York City's LaGuardia Airport.", u'Teri Polo was cast for her sarcastic edge.', u'Meet the Parents (2000) is actually a remake of a 1992 Independent film of the same name. The 75 minute short film starred Greg Glienna and Mary Ruth Clarke, who also wrote the script. Glienna also directed on the film on a budget of about $100,000. Unable to find a distributor for their film, the filmmakers eventually sold the rights to Universal Studios.', u"Look closely and you'll see that the car chase scene is largely comprised of close-ups of Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro. The actors shot their scenes on separate nights.", u'Robert De Niro originally wanted to train the cat himself but then realized that would take up to about 6 months of his life. Instead, he would carry kibble in all his pockets which helped him enjoy a very co-operative relationship with the animal.', u'On July 18, 2005, a regularly scheduled American Airlines flight from Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport to San Juan, Puerto Rico was diverted back to Fort Lauderdale forty minutes into the flight, after a flight attendant found a crumpled napkin that read "Bomb, bomb, bomb...meet the parents." The airplane was met by a bomb squad of the local sheriff\'s office as well as the FBI, whose agents questioned the plane\'s 176 passengers about the note.', u'Christina Ricci was considered for the role of Pam Byrnes.', u'Steven Soderbergh was originally attached to direct.', u'Greg tells the stewardess on the plane to "shut your pie hole;" Robert De Niro said the same thing several times in This Boy\'s Life (1993).', u'Included among the "1,001 Movies You Must See Before You Die," edited by Steven Schneider.', u'The crew trained the cat in the movie to climb the side of the house, by calling it with a buzzer to get a treat.', u"The Victor Talbot's tuxedo store in the film is located in Greenvale, New York.", u'Production designers built the full interior of the house inside a giant armory in Brooklyn, New York. They wanted a "tasteful, Republican" feel, so the colors are red, white, and blue.', u'Earned back its initial budget of $55 million in just 11 days.', u'Although set in Chicago, none of the film was actually shot there.', u'Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor did an uncredited rewrite of the screenplay. The poem that Robert De Niro reads about his deceased mother was one of their contributions as was the climactic airport sequence.', u'Director Jay Roach tried to keep Ben Stiller off-balance by not letting him know if Robert De Niro liked his work.', u"The of original opening of Meet the Parents (2000) was too expensive to film. It featured Greg proposing to Pam during a Cubs game at Wrigley Field-and failing spectacularly. To save money (the film had a $55 million budget), they had Greg's failed proposal take place outside of a school instead.", u'Director Jay Roach said that they were not making a comedy, they were making "a broken love story."', u"At one point in the film's development, Steven Spielberg was set to direct.", u'The cat, "Mr. Jinx," was played by a cat named Mishka.', u'Remained in the US top 10 box office for 11 weeks.', u'The 7th highest grossing film of 2000.', u'In the first dinner scene when Jack asks Greg to say grace and Pam tells him that Greg is Jewish, Greg says, "It\'s not like I\'m a rabbi." In that same year, Ben Stiller played a rabbi in the film Keping the Faith (2000).', u"The burglary alarm system at Jack's house is of a Magnum Alert MA1000e type.", u'James Rebhorn and Tom McCarthy both also appeared in two espionage thrillers of 2009 that starred Clive Owen. Rebhorn was in The International (2009) and McCarthy was in Duplicity (2009).', u'Blythe Danner said her character was inspired by the famous comedienne Gracie Allen.', u'American Humane Association monitored the animal action. No animals were harmed. Scenes appearing to place animals in jeopardy were simulated. AHA200802-2', u'In the movie Jack\'s drink of choice is a Tom Collins. "Tom Collins" is also the alias de Niro\'s character in Casino, Sam Rothstein, uses to register his personal safe deposit box.', u"Eight years earlier, Ben Stiller parodied Robert De Niro's performance as Max Cady in Cape Fear (1991) on The Ben Stiller Show (1992).", u"Spencer Breslin: one of Pam's students.", u'When Greg is having his outburst on the plane, a man in the background to the left can be seen trying not to laugh.', u'In an early scene, Greg (Ben Stiller) and Jack (Robert De Niro) share differing opinions about the theme of the song "Puff the Magic Dragon." In the film\'s concluding scene, when Jack is watching Greg on his surveillance tapes, "Puff the Magic Dragon" is playing softly in the background.']

title: The Adventures of Rocky & Bullwinkle
plot_outline: When enemies Boris, Natasha and Fearless leader escape into the real world with a nefarious scheme, Rocky & Bullwinkle do the same and team up with a young F.B.I. agent to stop the trio.
keywords: [u'fbi', u'squirrel', u'moose', u'deforestation', u'lighthouse', u'based-on-tv-series', u'glowing-eye', u'awareness-that-one-is-a-cartoon-character', u'spoof', u'lifting-someone-into-the-air', u'reference-to-pbs', u'farce', u'breaking-the-fourth-wall', u'u.s.-president', u'road-comedy', u'part-live-action', u'satire', u'road-trip', u'spy', u'hypnotism', u'hollywood-sign', u'cartoon-reality-crossover', u'mad-scientist', u'part-animation', u'part-computer-animation', u'courtroom', u'actor-playing-multiple-roles', u'college', u'helicopter', u'pun', u'fugitive', u'self-referential', u'airplane', u'studio-logo-segues-into-film', u'inner-child', u'product-placement', u'internet', u'based-on-cartoon', u'hollywood-california', u'world-domination', u"catching-food-in-one's-mouth", u'celebrity', u'white-house', u'character-name-in-title']
taglines: [u"It's not the same old bull.", u'You will believe a squirrel can fly.', u'This Summer, Evil Meets Its Moose.', u'This Summer the real world is becoming a little more Animated.....', u'This Summer, the fur will fly, the moose will drive and the world will discover this is not the same old bull.', u'DeNiro...Russo...Alexander...Moose...Squirrel']
trivia: [u'This film was originally in pre-production in the early 1990s, with Danny DeVito and Meryl Streep set to play Boris and Natasha. Legal problems with copyrights prevented the film being made until several years later.', u'For the narration, Keith Scott is doing an imitation of the voice of the late William Conrad, who had been the narrator for the original animated adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle, Rocky and His Friends (1959).', u'Palm trees that were left on the Chapman University campus after the filming of Crimson Tide (1995) were covered and disguised as redwood trees.', u'Fearless Leader (Robert De Niro) says to Boris & Natasha "You talkin\' to me?...There\'s no one else here, so you must be talking to me". This is a reference to his most famous lines in Taxi Driver (1976).', u'The students in the film were actually real students of Chapman University, where part of the film takes place.', u"Kenan Thompson and Kel Mitchell, a comedy duo of the mid '90s, play Lewis and Martin respectively. A nod to another comedy duo, Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin.", u'When Fearless Leader is explaining a way to kill a cartoon character a spy asks him "What about that movie Roger Rabbit?" June Foray the voice of Rocky and Natasha starred in Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988) as the voices of Lena Hyena and Wheezy the weasel.', u'The University infirmary is labeled "J. Ward", a homage to Rocky and Bullwinkle creator, Jay Ward.', u'The businesses lining the highways have some rather unusual names. Among them are "Lotta Room Motel", "Pump Her Up" (gas station), "Beefy Buns" (fast food), and (glimpsed briefly through the driver\'s window of the truck) "Boob Mart".', u"The name of Bullwinkle's alma mater is Wossamotta U.", u'Jason Alexander admitted to doing the movie strictly for the money.', u'As Fearless Leader, Robert De Niro, known for being a method actor, is the first actor to interpret a cartoon character as a method performance.', u'Joe Pesci and Cher turned down the roles of Boris and Natasha.', u'This was the last film from the Rocky and Bullwinkle franchise and the last to be a live action movie until 14 years later when Mr. Peabody & Sherman (2014) was released and became the first film to be a computer animated film for the franchise.', u'When Rocky and Bullwinkle arrive at Wossamata U, Keenan Thompson and Kel Mitchell\'s characters mention how the university has been live-action since 1964, once the show went into reruns. Keenan then turns to Kel and jokes, "That\'ll never happen to us, right?" To which Kel responds, "Right" as they wink at each other. Ironically, their show "Keenan and Kel" on Nick had just ended a month before the film\'s release, and went into reruns shortly after.', u"Rene Russo met June Foray at the film's table reading. By her own account, Russo was very nervous about taking on the role of Natasha Fatale and requested Foray to demonstrate the voice; Foray graciously obliged.", u"The young Karen Sympathy was played by Julia McAnuff' who's the young daughter of the movie director Des McAnuff.", u'Billy Crystal and John Goodman who played the Oklahoma cop and the mattress salesman would later star in the movie Monsters, Inc. (2001) as the voices of Mike and Sulley and would come out a year later after this films release.', u'Robert De Niro said in an interview that he only did this film purely for the money.', u'Monica Potter was originally cast as Karen Sympathy.', u";Keith Scott' used his same narrator voice that he previously did for George of the Jungle (1997) and later it's sequel George of the Jungle 2 (2003).", u'One of two films released during the summer of 2000 to feature both Piper Perabo and John Goodman. The other being Coyote Ugly (2000). They share the screen in both films.', u'June Foray, one of the surviving members of the original Rocky and His Friends (1959), who created the voice of Rocket J. Squirrel, does Rocky\'s voice for this film. She also recreates the voice of Natasha (when Natasha is in cartoon form) and her ubiquitous "old woman" voice from the old series as the voice of the narrator\'s mother.', u"The second Universal's live-action/animated hybrid film, after Balto (1995).", u"June Foray's second film from Universal Pictures after Problem Child 2 (1991).", u'As the Oklahoma cop is arresting Karen Sympathy, Rocky protests, "But she really is with the FBI!" The cop responds, "Yeah, and I\'m really John Goodman." This is an inside joke, because John Goodman is actually playing the cop.', u"Kenan Thompson's first live action animated film role. His next one is Fat Albert (2004).", u"Des McAnuff: The first person to turn off their TV after Bullwinkle's speech."]

trivia: [u"Robert De Niro's face would sometimes ache for days after tensing his jaw to speak in his post-stroke scenes.", u'Rusty\'s line, "It costs a lot to look this cheap," is also a personal quote attributed to Dolly Parton.', u'The line "I\'m more of a man than you\'ll ever be and more of a woman than you\'ll ever get" was first uttered by Antonio Fargas as \'Lindy\' in Car Wash (1976).', u'When Robert De Niro read the screenplay, he had only one question for Joel Schumacher: "When do we start shooting?"', u'Joel Schumacher conceived the idea for the film from personal experience. One of his close friends suffered a series of strokes and had to relearn how to speak through singing lessons.', u"Co-stars Chris Bauer and Skipp Sudduth also co-starred in the television series Third Watch (1999), which debuted the same year as the film's release."]

title: Wag the Dog
plot_outline: Shortly before an election, a spin-doctor and a Hollywood producer join efforts to fabricate a war in order to cover up a presidential sex scandal.
keywords: [u'election', u'president', u'scandal', u'hollywood', u'death', u'albania', u'spin-doctor', u'cover-up', u'presidential-candidate', u'political-corruption', u'corruption', u'political-conspiracy', u'political-cover-up', u'american-president', u'presidential-comedy', u'political-comedy', u'political-candidate', u'election-campaign', u'political-campaign', u'presidential-campaign', u'three-word-title', u'surveillance-camera', u'plane-crash', u'reference-to-king-kong', u'sneaker', u'baseball-metaphor', u'reference-to-howdy-doody', u'reference-to-plato', u'lhasa-apso', u'reference-to-arnold-schwarzenegger', u'dog', u'reference-to-jfk-assassination', u'press-secretary', u'white-house', u'rapist', u'illegal-alien', u'reference-to-ronald-reagan', u'political-assassination', u'anti-psychotic', u'reference-to-boog-powell', u'mental-patient', u'press-conference', u'reference-to-john-f.-kennedy', u'voter', u'reference-to-cecil-b.-demille', u'computer-generated-imagery', u'reference-to-davy-crockett', u'stretch-limousine', u'mansion', u'movie-making', u'kitten', u'reference-to-john-belushi', u'man-with-glasses', u'imperative-in-title', u'animal-in-title', u'tanning-bed', u'washington-d.c.', u'u.s.-president', u'satire', u'real-life-parallel', u'movie-producer', u'airplane-accident', u'fake-war', u'shoe', u'media-manipulation', u'political-satire', u'prisoner', u'theme-song', u'cat', u'cia', u'media-hype', u'rape', u'murder', u'black-comedy', u'producing', u'conspiracy', u'senator', u'secret-service', u'military', u'political-consultant', u'presidential-election', u'video-manipulation', u'based-on-book', u'independent-film', u'based-on-novel']
taglines: [u'Is this life imitating art in the film that preceded the biggest news story of 1998.', u'A Hollywood producer. A Washington spin-doctor. When they get together, they can make you believe anything.', u'A comedy about truth, justice and other special effects.', u'Why does a dog wag its tail?  Because a dog is smarter than its tail. If the tail were smarter, the tail would wag the dog.']
trivia: [u'After this film started production and before its release, US President Bill Clinton became involved in a sex scandal and threatened military action against Iraq.', u'"Why change horses midstream?" was originally a campaign slogan for Abraham Lincoln during the Civil War.', u'During the filming of Wag the Dog (1997), director Barry Levinson and stars Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro had an impromptu co-incidental meeting at a Washington hotel with then American President Bill Clinton. Clinton asked de Niro: "So what\'s this movie about ?. De Niro looked over to Levinson, hoping that he would answer the question. Levinson, in turn, looked over to Hoffman. Hoffman, realizing there was no one else to pass the buck to, is quoted as saying, "So I just started to tap dance. I can\'t even remember what I said."', u'"A good plan today is better than a perfect plan tomorrow", a line of dialogue in the film spoken by Conrad Brean (Robert De Niro), is a real-life quotation from WWII General George S. Patton.', u'The talk show phone number, (800) 555-0199, is common to many films and television shows because this is the only number that has been reserved by the phone company as an allowable "fake" 800 number for media usage.', u'Dustin Hoffman ad-libbed the line: "He didn\'t sell it".', u'The scene in which shoes laced together are hanging from telephone and electric wires was shot on East Capitol Street a few blocks behind the U.S. Capitol. The production crew left several pairs of shoes behind and they remained hanging on the wires for years.', u'Both lead actors, Robert De Niro and Dustin Hoffman, made the movie for no upfront salary.', u'The character of Winifred Ames, played by actress Anne Heche, was originally written as a man.', u'The film\'s opening prologue states: "Why does a dog wag its tail? Because a dog is smarter than its tail. If the tail were smarter, the tail would wag the dog".', u'Dustin Hoffman based the mannerisms and delivery for his film industry producer character of Stanley Motss on both his father and on real life legendary Hollywood producer Robert Evans.', u"The picture was filmed in twenty-eight days, during a gap in the production of this film's director Barry Levinson's other movie Sphere (1998).", u"The 'American Dream' segment with the choir singing is a clear spoof at the USA for Africa's 'We Are the World'. 'Willie Nelson' - who plays Johnny Dean in this film and conducts the choir - was one of the many artists who appeared singing at the 'We Are the World' clip.", u'Actor Craig T. Nelson and director Barry Levinson combined to do a stand-up comedy routine early in their careers.', u'The name of Sergeant William Schumann (Woody Harrelson)\'s medication, "Prozalium", is a combination of Prozac and Valium.', u'According to the Wikipedia website, "the title of the film [Wag the Dog (1997)] comes from the idiomatic English-language expression \'the tail wagging the dog\'." It is shown at the film\'s start and reads "Why does the dog wag its tail? Because a dog is smarter than its tail. If the tail were smarter, it would wag the dog".', u'The claim of Stanley Motss (Dustin Hoffman) that "there is no Academy Award for producing" is (technically) incorrect, since the Oscar for Best Picture has always been given to the main producer(s) of a film.', u"The political talk show at the end of the film lists its phone number as 1-(800)-555-0199. This number is also Lester Burnham's office number in the film American Beauty (1999) as well as Lowell Bergman's fax number in the film The Insider (1999)", u'The face of the American President character in the film is never seen and he is only ever seen filmed from the back.', u'According to the Urban Dictionary, the meaning of the phrase \'Wag the Dog\' is "when something of secondary importance improperly takes on the role of something of primary importance. The expression pre-dates the movie by the same name [Wag the Dog (1997)], and was NOT coined by said movie."', u"The film's cast includes four Academy Award winners: Robert De Niro, Dustin Hoffman, Robert Richardson, and director Barry Levinson, with the two latter appear in minor cameo roles; whilst the movie also features two Oscar nominees, Woody Harrelson and William H. Macy. Hoffman is a Best Actor Oscar Winner for both Rain Man (1988) and Kramer vs. Kramer (1979) whilst De Niro is a Best Actor Oscar Winner for Raging Bull (1980) and Best Supproting Actor Oscar winner for The Godfather: Part II (1974). Both de Niro and Hoffmann have been nominated for Oscars each on seven occasions including the two above-mentioned wins each.", u'The movie\'s closing credits state: "SPECIAL THANKS TO . . . THE CAST AND CREW for completing principal photography in 29 days!".', u'In the funeral scene, soldiers in the military band are played by members of the Riverside Community College marching band.', u'Cinematographer Robert Richardson appears in a cameo in the scene in the studio where the fake footage of the fake war is filmed.', u'With a twenty-nine day production schedule and a modest US $15 million budget, the picture relied on an intelligent storytelling and genteel character development to dramatize the ultimate whitewash at the White House.', u'Three title cards of note relating to this film featured in the movie\'s related 25 minute DVD documentary "Wag the Dog: From Washington to Hollywood ...And Back (1998) (V)" state: (1) "Just a few weeks after Wag the Dog (1997) was released, President Clinton [Bill Clinton] was accused of having an affair with a White House intern"; (2) "The 1992 documentary, The War Room (1993), shows the actual love-hate relationship between politicians and the media that is parodied in Wag the Dog (1997)"; and (3) "So will the next generation be able to tell the difference between real news and news that has been faked?".', u'Star Dustin Hoffman and director Barry Levinson did this movie whilst on a break from making the movie Sphere (1998).', u'While the genesis for the picture was originally a novel titled "American Hero" (1993) by Larry Beinhart, which was adapted for the screen by Hilary Henkin, the producers brought writer David Mamet aboard, because "he is certainly the premiere playwright of his generation," Levinson said. "David\'s way of looking at the world was a perfect fit. Not a lot of movies are strong dialogue pieces anymore. But this is sharp writing; there\'s an edgy wit infused into the dialogue."', u'Despite their hectic schedules, director-producer Barry Levinson and co-screenwriter David Mamet were able to communicate via phone and fax to put together what they felt was a viable draft script. Once the screenplay was delivered, producer Jane Rosenthal rallied the troops, and quickly assembled a table reading with Dustin Hoffman, Robert De Niro, Anne Heche, and a number of other talented actors, many of whom appear in the film.', u"One of numerous collaborations of actor William H. Macy and the film's co-screenwriter David Mamet.", u'The Using English website states that "to \'wag the dog\' means to purposely divert attention from what would otherwise be of greater importance, to something else of lesser significance. By doing so, the lesser-significant event is catapulted into the limelight, drowning proper attention to what was originally the more important issue. The expression comes from the saying that \'a dog is smarter than its tail\', but if the tail were smarter, then the tail would \'wag the dog\'. The expression \'wag the dog\' was elaborately used as theme of the movie. \'Wag the Dog\', a 1997 film starring \'Robert de Niro\' and Dustin Hoffman, produced and directed by Barry Levinson".', u'Initiated as a group project by producer Jane Rosenthal, director and producer Barry Levinson, and actors Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro, the picture was conceived as a witty, incisive inside look at American politics, pundits, Hollywood and the media, as a war is waged to divert public attention from a national disgrace, an unthinkable sex scandal in the White House Oval Office.', u'The nick-name of Sergeant William Schumann (Woody Harrelson) was "The Old Shoe".', u'Government and intelligence organizations featured and/or referenced in the movie include the White House, the FBI, the CIA, the NSA, the Pentagon, and the US American Government.', u'Co-screenwriter Hilary Henkin as the same sounding first name as former US Senator, US Secretary of State, and 2016 Democrat Presidential Candidate Hillary Clinton. At the time that Wag the Dog (1997) was made and first released, Hillary Clinton was the US First Lady (FLOTUS).', u'Star Dustin Hoffman had already starred in a movie called "American Hero" (aka "Hero") [See: American Hero (1997)]. The name of the source novel by Larry Beinhart that Wag the Dog (1997) was based on was called "American Hero" (1993).', u'The film\'s closing credits declare that the picture was: "Filmed on location in LOS ANGELES, CA [California, USA], BAKERSFIELD, CA [California, USA], and WASHINGTON D.C. [District of Columbia, USA]."', u'The picture was nominated for two Academy Awards in 1998 a the70th year ceremony, Dustin Hoffman for the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role, and the Best Writing, Screenplay Based on Material Previously Produced or Published Oscar, for Hilary Henkin and David Mamet, but the movie failed to take home an Oscar in either category.', u"The film was entered into and then selected to screen in competition to compete for prestigious the Golden Bear and the Silver Bear awards at the annual 48th Berlin International Film Festival but lost out on the Golden Bear to Walter Salles' Central Station (1998) but won a Special Jury Prize Silver Bear for its director Barry Levinson.", u"Both of the movie's two top-billed lead stars, Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro, have won two Academy Awards for acting. Hoffman is a Best Actor Oscar Winner for both Rain Man (1988) and Kramer vs. Kramer (1979) whilst De Niro is a Best Actor Oscar Winner for Raging Bull (1980) and a Best Supporting Actor Oscar winner for The Godfather: Part II (1974). Both de Niro and Hoffmann have been nominated for Oscars each on seven occasions including the above-mentioned wins for each.", u'One of four cinema movie collaborations of actors Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro. The films are Sleepers (1996), Meet the Fockers (2004), Wag the Dog (1997), and Little Fockers (2010). Of these, both Sleepers (1996) and Ghost dog - samuraiden tapaan (1999) were directed by Barry Levinson.', u'The film was nominated for inclusion in the AFI (American Film Institute)\'s "100 Years . . . 100 Laughs" list.', u'"This is nothing!", the recurring phrase spoken by Stanley Motss (Dustin Hoffman) in the movie, was nominated for the AFI (American Film Institute)\'s "100 Years . . . 100 Movie Quotes" list.', u'The letter "t" in the character name of Stanley Motss (Dustin Hoffman) is silent with the surname last name pronounced as if it were "Moss".', u"One of five cinema movie collaborations of actor Dustin Hoffman and director Barry Levinson. The films are Sphere (1998), Sleepers (1996), Rain Man (1988), Wag the Dog (1997), and Tootsie (1982). The latter was the only one of these five pictures that Levinson did not direct as he was one of the movie's uncredited screenwriters. Hoffman won the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role Oscar for Rain Man (1988), which also won the Best Picture Academy Award, and the Best Director Oscar for Levinson, winning 4 Academy Awards in total.", u'The film was made and first released in the year if 1997 which was during the presidency of Democrat American President Bill Clinton which ran between 1992 (election) / 1993 (inauguration) and 1996 (election) and 2000 (election: ineligible to be a candidate) / 2001 (end of term).', u"Actor Woody Harrelson has appeared in such American politics movies / politically themed pictures as LBJ (2016), where he plays the title nick-name character of former Democrat American President Lyndon Johnson, Game Change (2012), Barry Levinson's political satire Wag the Dog (1997), Battle in Seattle (2007), and Welcome to Sarajevo (1997). The following year after LBJ (2016), Harrelson played the title character in _Wilson (2017), but this was not former Democrat American President 'Woodrow Wilson', as with the earlier _Wilson (1944_.", u"Robert Richardson: Uncredited, the film's director of photography as a man at the television studio.", u'Jay Leno: As himself.', u'Jim Belushi: As himself.', u'Barry Levinson: with his back to the camera in the opening scene at the movie studio.', u'Barry Levinson: [Ralph Tabakin] Ralph (Southern Man) has appeared in every Levinson picture from Diner (1982) to Liberty Heights (1999).']

taglines: [u"Be warned. It's alive.", u"It's Alive.", u'Be warned.']
trivia: [u'Robert De Niro studied stroke victims to get a purchase on speech that is struggling to emerge.', u'It was during the filming of this movie, that Kenneth Branagh, then married to Emma Thompson, fell in love with Helena Bonham Carter.', u"Producer Francis Ford Coppola had originally planned to direct the film himself as a companion piece to Bram Stoker's Dracula (1992), but eventually stepped back to let Kenneth Branagh direct. Coppola later regretted his decision after several disagreements with Branagh during filming.", u'The producers were hesitant about casting John Cleese as Professor Waldman since he was considered a comic actor with the looks to match. To make Cleese appear more serious, they fitted him with a prosthetic chin and teeth that made his looks more sharp and grave.', u'After viewing a rough cut, Francis Ford Coppola insisted on cutting the first half hour of the film. When Director Kenneth Branagh refused, Coppola publicly denounced the film.', u'Frank Darabont has said in interviews that he was displeased with the finished film, feeling that Kenneth Branagh had mishandled the project.', u'Kenneth Branagh apparently banned the term "Monster" from the set. He insisted that everyone refer to De Niro\'s character the way he was identified in the credits, as "The Sharp-Featured Man".', u'Kenneth Branagh originally wanted Emma Thompson for the role of Elizabeth. However, she had been offered the lead in Carrington (1995) and Branagh agreed that this would be a better part for her.', u"The amniotic fluid in which the Creature was brought to life, was really boiling gelatin. During filming, Robert De Niro and Kenneth Branagh slipped and fell in the stuff so much, that a huge split appeared in De Niro's prosthetic suit, which had to be avoided by the cameras.", u'The film takes place in 1773, 1785, 1788, 1793, and 1794.', u'Willem Dafoe was offered the role of Victor Frankenstein.', u"Kate Winslet auditioned for the role of Elizabeth in this movie. Helena Bonham Carter was selected for the role, but Branagh was so impressed by Winslet, that he offered her the part of Ophelia in Hamlet (1996). Carter played Ophelia in Franco Zefferelli's Hamlet (1990).", u'This was the first film directed by Kenneth Branagh not to feature Emma Thompson.', u'Sir Ian Holm previously played Dr. Victor Frankenstein, and the creature, in Mystery and Imagination: Frankenstein (1968).', u'Roman Polanski was approached to direct.', u'G\xe9rard Depardieu and Andy Garcia were early suggestions for the role of the Creature.', u'Kenneth Branagh, John Cleese, Robert Hardy, and Helena Bonham Carter appeared in the Harry Potter film franchise.', u'Christopher Lambert was cast as Henry Clerval, but replaced by Tom Hulce before filming.', u'John Cleese shot his part in two weeks.', u'First cinema film of Hugh Bonneville, who plays the bullying medical student, Schiller.', u'Sir Sean Connery was asked to play Professor Waldman.', u'Fay Ripley filmed a small role, she was bitten by Robert De Niro, but her scenes never made the final cut.', u'Richard Briers (Grandfather) worked two weeks.', u'Kenneth Branagh was keen to cast G\xe9rard Depardieu as the Creature, but Columbia Pictures felt that he would not have strong enough box-office appeal. Branagh later cast Depardieu as Reynaldo in Hamlet (1996).', u'At one point, Tim Burton was being courted to direct, with Columbia Pictures eyeing Arnold Schwarzenegger as the Creature.', u'Francis Ford Coppola claims that Mary Shelley\'s name was included in the title because he has a tradition of putting the author\'s names in the titles of his movies that are adapted from novels, such as "Mario Puzo\'s The Godfather (1972)", "Bram Stoker\'s Bram Stoker\'s Dracula (1992)" and "John Grisham\'s The Rainmaker (1997)". Others have claimed, however, that Shelley\'s name was included in the title to avoid legal action from Universal Studios, who claimed to own the rights to the simple title Frankenstein (1931).', u'Kenneth Branagh and Sir Ian Holm appeared in Henry V (1989).', u'Robert De Niro and Sir Ian Holm appeared in Brazil (1985).', u'This film contains several references to previous Frankenstein films: The Creature is brought to life in a metallic vat, as in Frankenstein (1910). Victor cuts an executed criminal from a hangman\'s noose, and uses the body for his experiments, as in Frankenstein (1931) and Young Frankenstein (1974). The Creature is reanimated with electrical charges. This is an invention of Hollywood. The book is silent on how Victor creates the Creature. Once the Creature comes to life, Victor triumphantly shouts, "It\'s alive!" The Creature\'s first spoken word is "friend". This is also the Creature\'s most frequently-used word, when he learns to speak in Bride of Frankenstein (1935). Victor uses the brain of a brilliant scientist and mentor for his Creature, as in The Curse of Frankenstein (1957). Justine Moritz\'s role is also expanded, and is made to fall in love with Victor in both films. Victor\'s mentor, who paved the road for his experiments, brings a severed arm back to life, and shows it to Victor, as in Frankenstein: The True Story (1973). The Creature hides in some cottagers\' pigsty, and secretly learns to speak and read from observing them through a peephole. In the book, the cottagers are foreign refugees. In this film, the cottagers are simply local townsfolk. This variation on the novel was first used in Terror of Frankenstein (1977). Victor revives a mangled and hideous Elizabeth after the Creature murders her, and Victor and the Creature then engage in a battle for her affection. Horrified, the reanimated Elizabeth takes her own life. The same events take place, almost exactly, in Roger Corman\'s Frankenstein Unbound (1990). A cholera epidemic sweeps through Ingolstadt, leaving Victor to believe that the Creature died from disease. Frankenstein (1992) also featured a cholera epidemic under very similar circumstances, even though it is not present in the novel.', u'Kenneth Branagh did an uncredited re-write on the script. One of his additions was the scene where the reanimated Elizabeth sets herself on fire.', u'The end version makes it look like Henry Clerval was killed, but deleted scenes show he and the Frankenstein Servants survive the fire.', u"Producers were resistant to William's on-screen death."]

title: A Bronx Tale
plot_outline: A father becomes worried when a local gangster befriends his son in the Bronx in the 1960s.
keywords: [u'first-love', u'father-son-relationship', u'gangster', u'money', u'bus', u'bar', u'african-american', u'racism', u'1960s', u'funeral-bouquet', u'mob-execution', u'immolation', u'u-turn', u'kissing-in-public', u'first-kiss', u'sicilian', u'motorcycle-gang', u'sprayed-with-beer', u'wolf-whistle', u'betting-on-a-horse', u'horse-race', u'reference-to-the-beatles', u'year-1968', u'tip', u'11-passes-in-a-row', u'crap-game', u'yankees-baseball-cap', u'fixing-a-bicycle', u'confessional', u'shot-multiple-times', u'baseball-bat', u'breaking-a-car-windshield', u'obscene-finger-gesture', u'pat-on-the-head', u'genuflecting', u'stickball', u'narrated-by-character', u'cadillac-convertible', u'reference-to-mickey-mantle', u'interracial-relationship', u'child-uses-drugs', u'child-swearing', u'brutality', u'racial-violence', u'racial-intolerance', u'urban-setting', u'nostalgia', u'new-york-city', u'bronx-new-york-city', u'place-name-in-title', u'produced-by-director', u'produced-by-actor', u'reference-to-rocky-marciano', u'work', u'shot-in-the-head', u'prayer', u'morality', u'little-boy', u'fire', u'confession', u'coffin', u'childhood-memory', u'car', u'burned-to-death', u'burned-bodies', u'biker-gang', u'white-male-black-female-relationship', u'interracial-romance', u'understanding', u'role-model', u'mob-boss', u'generation-gap', u'friendship', u'coming-of-age', u'affection', u'directed-by-star', u'public-transit', u'police-lineup', u'murder-witness', u'gambling', u'craps', u'bus-driver', u'boxing-match', u'blacks-versus-italians', u'black-american', u'italian-american', u'murder', u'molotov-cocktail', u'loyalty', u'funeral', u'violence', u'racial-slur', u'based-on-true-story', u'based-on-play', u'independent-film', u'racist']
taglines: [u'One man lives in the neighborhood, another man owns it. A devoted father battles the local crime boss for the life of his son.']
trivia: [u'When Robert De Niro had trouble finding a suitable actor to portray Eddie Mush, he asked Chazz Palminteri if they could find the real Eddie Mush to play himself. They found Eddie Montanaro in the same neighborhood still losing bets. After casting him, they became worried that Eddie Mush would "jinx" the film. On Montanaro\'s first day of filming, it rained.', u"The story, written by Chazz Palminteri, is adapted from his autobiographical one-man play. His real name is Calogero Lorenzo Palminteri. Several studios approached him to purchase the film rights, with at least one offering $1 million, but Palminteri refused to sell them unless he could write the screenplay and play the role of Sonny. None of the studios agreed as they wanted to hire another actor. Then Robert De Niro offered to go into a 50/50 partnership with all of Palminteri's conditions met as long as De Niro could direct and play Lorenzo. Palminteri agreed and their contract was sealed on a handshake.", u'Casting scouts searched around New York City and Long Island for a teenager to play the role of Calogero. A scout noticed Lillo Brancato on Jones Beach. For most of his childhood, Brancato had done impersonations of Robert De Niro and was often told that he resembled De Niro. When he performed an impersonation for the scout, she immediately cast him.', u'Although it was "A Bronx Tale", virtually all of it was filmed in Astoria and Jackson Heights, Queens. It was easier to capture the period in those locations where many buildings from the 1950s still stood.', u'De Niro wanted Palminteri to be involved in every aspect of production. Palminteri was involved in casting, scouting locations, editing and sound mixing.', u"Kathrine Narducci brought her 9-year-old son to the open casting call to audition for the role of young Calogero. When she saw that the role of Calogero's mother was available she asked if she could also audition and got the part.", u'In the Biker Bar Fight scene, a curly haired character with a goatee is often mistaken for an early cameo appearance of Rob Schneider. This is actually a real New York City member of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club.', u'The original 1988 Broadway production of "A Bronx Tale" by Chazz Palminteri re-opened at the Walter Kerr Theatre on October 25, 2007, ran for 111 performances and closed on February 24, 2008.    Chazz still performs A Bronx Tale as his one-man play approx 25 cities a year.', u"Dedicated to Robert De Niro's father, Robert De Niro Sr., who died in 1993.", u"Robert De Niro's directorial debut.", u'At one point in the film, Sonny tells Calogero that he read \'Niccolo Machiavelli\' during his time in prison. He later tells Calogero how he runs his gang - that he\'d rather be feared than loved, because fear is something that he can control, while love is not. Sonny then goes on to stress it\'s important not to give his people so little that fear crosses over into hate. This concept of leadership stems directly from Machiavelli\'s most famous book, "The Prince."    Chazz says it\'s better for Chazz to be loved but for Sonny to be feared.', u'Robert De Niro had to get a CDL-B to drive the buses in the movie. Boston, MA MBTA turned him down for training for his CDL, citing he was not an "employee". NYCTA happily instructed him and he received his CDL-B w/Airbrakes for the movie.', u'According to an interview with Lillo Brancato on 20/20 (1978), Brancato began using drugs during the making of this film. He stated that the first time he used drugs was right before the scene in which Calogero asks Sonny "Is it better to be loved or feared?" Palminteri and De Niro cautioned Brancato numerous times but to no avail.', u'Both of the actors who play the Italian-American Calogero are of Latino descent. Francis Capra is of half-Dominican descent. Lillo Brancato is of Colombian descent and was adopted by an Italian family.', u'At one point, Lorenzo (Robert De Niro) tells C that he dissaproves of interracial relationships. Robert De Niro has been married twice, both times to African American women.', u'The Street in front of the Chez Bippy bar is 30th Avenue in Astoria Queens, New York. Now called the American Sports Center and is located at 4402 30th Ave Astoria, NY 11103.', u'The fictional motorcycle gang Satan\'s Messengers is obviously based on the notorious and real Hell\'s Angels. There have been dozens of fictionalized versions to the Hell\'s Angels in movies and TV shows with convoluted variations on their name. Here, in A Bronx Tale, the word Messenger comes closest to the true intent of the real name; the literal translation of the Greek word "aggelos" from which the word "Angel" is derived, means "messenger".', u'Frank Vincent was to appear in a scene as the boss of the Mafia family but the scene was not filmed.', u'Some scenes were filmed at William Cullen Bryant High School in Long Island City.', u'When Lorenzo and Calogero clean out the bus at City Island, a Wonderland advertisement can be seen on the bus.', u'The alternative band The Ataris, use lines from this movie in the background of their song "Your Boyfriend Sucks"', u'First Film by Savoy Pictures.', u'The horse designated in the stock footage as "Kryptonite" (in the Aqueduct scene) per the jockey\'s silks is owned by Harbor View Farms. Harbor View Farms owned and campaigned Triple Crown winner Affirmed.', u'During the scene with the lineup against the bar there is a cop in the background who picks up a child by the back of his pants and Carries him over a few feet', u'Body count: 6.']

title: The Night We Never Met
plot_outline: Sam has a problem with his roommates: they are disgusting, and don't seem to share his views on responsibility...
keywords: [u'roommate', u'cheese-shop', u'dominatrix', u'time-share', u'new-york-city', u'mistaken-identity', u'apartment', u'adultery', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'A comedy with room for romance.']
trivia: [u"Annabella Sciorra would go on to star on the hit series, Law & Order: Criminal Intent with Chris Noth as team number two on the series behind the shows original stars, Vincent D'Onofrio and Kathryn Erbe for two seasons due to D'Onofrio's personal health issues due to overwork. The series was executive produced by Warren Leight, the writer and director of this film.", u"Kevin Anderson and Jeanne Tripplehorn would go on two appear in two popular novel to film adaptations after this film was released in the Spring of 1993. Anderson would appear in Rising Sun starring Sean Connery and Wesley Snipes and Tripplehorn would appear in the hit, The Firm starring Tom Cruise, with whom Anderson co-starred in Cruise's breakout film, Risky Business, ten years earlier. Both released in June 1993. Both Anderson and Tripplehorn play important vital roles in each film.", u'Matthew Broderick and Dominick Chianese both worked with Oscar Winning Director Sidney Lumet. Broderick had done with Family Business in 1989 and Chianese would play a vital role in, Night Falls On Manhattan, which began filming a few years after this film was completed.', u'The schedule set up by Brian\'s Secretary for the use of the "Lion\'s Den" was for the following days:Monday: Sam Tuesday: Ellen Wednesday: Brian Thursday: Ellen Friday: Brian Saturday: Sam', u"Debut of Comedian Lewis Black as Michael Mantell's brother, Marty Holder in the film although he's not mentioned as such except during the End Credits.", u"The film was shot in actual New York locations around Greenwich Village. Brian's apartment building (The Lions Den) is located in the East Village and is the exact same block where Addicted To Love would film in 1996, which also starred Matthew Broderick.", u"Matthew Broderick would go on to co-star in the 1997 comedy, Addicted To Love with Meg Ryan which shares a few similarities with this film. The main one is Broderick's appearance in which he also sports a beard and dresses in similar clothing to and the character's name is also Sam like in this film, which could be a variation of this character in this film reinterpreted by Broderick for that film.", u'Matthew Broderick and Christine Baranski would go on to appear in the remake of The Stepford Wives in 2004.', u'The occupations of each characters are: Sam (Cook/Food Specialist at Dean & DeLuca), Ellen (A dental assistant) and Brian (Stockbroker).', u'The debut of Bitty Schram of the hit series, Monk as the blonde salesclerk with long red fingernails (her trademark) and would appear in One Fine Day with a similar look only more professional.', u"Michael Imperioli who plays one of the customer's at the Dry Cleaners owned by Annabella Sciorra in the film, would go on to appear on Law & Order, filling in for Jessie L. Martin's character at the exact same time (2005), that Sciorra would be co-starring on Law & Order: Criminal Intent as a regular and in which Warren Leight's the films' writer/director would be the Executive Producer and the film's cinematographer, John Thomas would be the primary DP on the series.", u'There are clues throughout the film that Sam and Ellen fall in love with each other indirectly and eventually do end up together. They include: Ellen\'s husband, Aaron refusing to make love to her in the apartment, Sam continual frustration of running into Pastel (his ex-girlfriend) finally putting her in her place, and all the ensuing bad dates that happen in the apartment, Sam\'s gifts to Ellen (paint, the Easel, the wooden pot for her plants), Ellen\'s use of his grandmother\'s blanket, the notes he leaves her regrading all of his horrible dates with his leftover dinner\'s hes made and when she walks into Dean & DeLuca asking for caviar and share a moment in which he gets excited when she tells him that she "trusts him".', u"It was Ellen's sister played by Christine Baranski, who suggested to her to have an affair to her in which she followed through on because she could tell that she had fallen in love with Matthew Broderick's character and wanted her to be happy.", u"Sam switches his Monday date with Brian's Wednesday's which causes the screw up and eventual problem with Ellen prompting her to sleep with Brian instead of Sam. This screw up also ruins Sam's seemingly successful date with Inga later in the film in which Brian's fiancee Janet shows up ruining it assuming Brian was in the apartment that night which was really Sam's sensing correctly that Brian did sleep with Ellen after finding the keys to the Lions Den in his pant pockets.", u"The only time all three characters are actually together in the same room throughout the entire movie is when after Sam wakes up and finds Ellen in the apartment sleeping on the chair with his grandmother's blanket and Brian returning to get the tuxedo for his wedding with Janet, which he wore the night he'd slept with Ellen, that morning.", u"After Ellen sleeps with Brian and admits to her husband that she did that very night (Friday) starts a chain of events that would lead to the final resolution in the film which includes Janet barging in on Sam's date with Inga with her running away (Saturday), Brian deciding to get rid the Lion's Den (Monday), Ellen's marriage to Aaron ending & Sam finally getting dumping Pastel at the club (both Saturday) and Brian marrying Janet and passing the torch of the Lions Den to Sam and Ellen (Sunday)"]
release_dates: [u'USA::30 April 1993', u'UK::27 August 1993', u'Denmark::3 December 1993', u'Germany::3 February 1994', u'France::4 May 1994', u'Portugal::4 August 1995', u'Japan::25 May 1996']

title: Thunderheart
plot_outline: A young mixed-blood FBI agent is assigned to work with a cynical veteran investigator on a murder on a poverty-stricken Sioux reservation.
keywords: [u'sioux', u'fbi', u'reservation', u'fbi-agent', u'murder', u'sioux-indian', u'badlands', u'jurisdiction', u'murder-investigation', u'south-dakota', u'native-american', u'medicine-man', u'tribal-elder', u'giving-the-finger', u'g-man', u'mineral-rights', u'tribal-dance', u'audio-tape', u'flashback', u'drumbeat', u'stray-dog', u'dirt-bike', u'helicopter-shot', u'car-chase', u'badger', u'spilled-milk', u"eagle's-feather", u'barter', u'tobacco', u'molotov-cocktail', u'fish-out-of-water', u'mr-magoo', u'reference-to-james-bond', u'schoolteacher', u'shooting-of-child', u'reference-to-sal-mineo', u'cemetery', u'reference-to-gary-cooper', u'reference-to-john-wayne', u'shot-to-death', u'motel', u'murder-mystery', u'rifle', u'showdown', u'trailer', u'cigarette-smoking', u'pipe-smoking', u'pow-wow', u'peace-pipe', u'roadblock', u'pump-action-shotgun', u'machine-gun', u'm-16', u'shotgun', u'suicide-by-gunshot', u'canyon', u'foot-chase', u'suspense', u'shot-in-the-chest', u'shot-in-the-arm', u'gunshot-wound', u'blood-on-shirt', u'fistfight', u'brawl', u'militant', u'buddy-cop', u'six-shooter', u'gunfight', u'modern-western', u'deer', u'cowboy-shirt', u'cowboy-boots', u'cowboy-hat', u'winchester-rifle', u'repeating-rifle', u'semiautomatic-pistol', u'shootout', u'pistol', u'revolver', u'shot-in-the-back', u'chase', u'm-4-machine-gun', u'police-brutality', u'beating', u'hero', u'tough-guy', u'ambush', u'calumet', u'tie', u'rebellion', u'mining', u'uranium', u'wristwatch', u'drive-by-shooting', u'undercover', u'vision', u'desert', u'chief', u'deal', u'tribal-police', u'mother-daughter-relationship', u'activist', u'wheelchair', u'roots', u'betrayal', u'sunglasses', u'wounded-knee', u'biracial', u'based-on-true-story', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'Two men from different worlds. Two cops after the same killer. Together they must uncover the secrets. Together they must discover the truth.']
trivia: [u'The movie is actually a thinly veiled account of real events that occurred on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation during the early to mid-Seventies. Exploration for Uranium, disease from irradiated water, the American Indian Movement (AIM) and the "Traditional" Natives fight against the Tribal government "Guardians Of the Oglala Nation (GOON\'s), and the FBI\'s assistance to the "Goons" by providing weaponry and other assistance are some of the things that are referred to in the movie that were true and documented by Writer/Director Michael Apted when he was a regular visitor to the Reservation during that time.', u'John Trudell (Jimmy Looks Twice) really did serve in Vietnam and was acting chairman of A.I.M. From 1973 to 1979.', u'Based on a true story, documented as Incident at Oglala (1992), which was also directed by Michael Apted.', u'During the early to mid-Seventies, there were fifty-seven unsolved murders on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation due to the fighting between the "Traditionals" and Tribal government sanctioned "goons". This made the Village of Pine Ridge (Pop. 1100) the "Murder Capitol of the Nation" with the highest number of violent death per capita in the United States.', u"The video clip which William Dawes shows Ray Levoi in the beginning of the film is actual footage of Native American activists rioting in Custer, South Dakota. The activists were protesting the change from a white man's charges from murder to second degree manslaughter, in the death of a Native American in Custer. They scuffled with the South Dakota Highway Patrol, set fire to the courthouse, and incurred property damage.", u'In the movie, Val Kilmer plays a character who is 1/4th Sioux. In real life, he is 1/4th Cherokee.', u'The movie contains several references to the original Wounded Knee incident, which took place on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in 1890. For instance, the character William Dawes shares a surname with Senator Henry Dawes, of Dawes Act notoriety. The Dawes Act\'s goal was to assimilate American Indians into white society. Additionally, Frank Coutelle refers to Walter Crow Horse as "Crowfoot". Crowfoot was the name of the first of Sitting Bull\'s sons to be shot and killed at the original Wounded Knee massacre.', u'Robert De Niro who produced this film later worked with Val Kilmer on Heat (1995).', u'Filming was done with the support of the Oglala Sioux people, who trusted Michael Apted and John Fusco to express their story.', u'Two hundred and fifty Native Americans worked as extras on the movie.', u'A fictitious Sal Mineo movie, "Arrows on the Prairie" is mentioned. Although the movie is fictional, Mineo did star as a young Sioux warrior in Tonka (1958) and later as a Cheyenne warrior in Cheyenne Autumn (1964).', u'Screenwriter John Fusco lived on the Pine Ridge Reservation for five years researching the script. There, he met Frank Fools Crow, a tribal elder who was the inspiration for Grandpa Sam Reaches.', u'Ted Thin Elk, who played an honoured Lakota medicine man, is a Lakota elder himself.', u'Maggie is based on activist Anna Mae Aquash, who was at one point the highest ranking woman in AIM. She was murdered in 1975.', u'The gravestone is a replica of the real one, with "Thunderheart" replacing the name "Swift Bird."', u'Filming took place over ten weeks, during which the cast endured temperatures over 100 \xb0F.', u'Screenwriter John Fusco became near-fluent in the Lakota language while living at Pine Ridge.', u"ARM is based on the American Indian Movement (AIM), a group that fights for Native American rights. The film is inspired by conflicts between AIM and the FBI in the '70s.", u"A paperback novel published by HarperCollins titled Thunderheart based on John Fusco's screenplay, was released on May 28, 1992. The book dramatises the fictionalised events of the Wounded Knee Incident, as depicted in the film. It expands on the ideas of how an FBI agent's assignment to uncover the truth behind violence on an Indian reservation leads to a wide-range conspiracy.", u'Kurt Russell, Tommy Lee Jones, Patrick Swayze, Michael Keaton, Dennis Quaid, Bruce Willis, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Harrison Ford, and Mel Gibson were considered to play Ray Levoi.', u'Michael Apted offered Marlon Brando the role of Frank "Cooch" Coutelle.', u"Jack Milton is based on Dick Wilson, the tribal chairman of the Pine Ridge Reservation from 1972-'76. Traditionalists tried to impeach Wilson in '73.", u'John Trudell, who played an Indian activist suspected of murder in the film inspired by the real life events surrounding Leonard Peltier, is in fact an Indian activist, as well as a poet and singer.', u'This is the first role for Sheila Tousey.', u"Val Kilmer and Sam Shepard's next movie together was Blind Horizon (2003).", u'Tom Cruise was suggested for the role of Ray Levoi.', u'Richard Gere was offered the role of Ray Levoi, but he was busy with Final Analysis (1992).', u'This is the second film James Horner composed that Val Kilmer appeared in. The first was Willow (1988).', u'The Squeeze (1977) was the first ever cinema thriller movie directed by British director Michael Apted. Apted would later go on to direct several other thrillers such as Enigma (2001), Enough (2002), Blink (1993), Thunderheart (1992), Gorky Park (1983), Class Action (1991), Extreme Measures (1996) and The World Is Not Enough (1999).', u'The 55th biggest grossing film of 1992.', u"Graham Green's character Walter makes a joke about Ray's partner (Sam Shepard) being 007. Michael Apted, the director of the film, would later go on to direct The World is Not Enough (1999).", u'Tommy Lee Jones, Scott Glenn, Brian cox, Robert De Niro, Harvey Keitel, dennis hopper, Jack Nicholson and Al Pacino were considered to play Frank Coutelle.', u"The character of Maggie Eagle Bear was likely based on AIM activist Anna Mae Aquash, who was found murdered along Highway 73 on the Pine Ridge Reservation in February 1975. Aquash had been a schoolteacher in an Indian school in Minneapolis - alluded to in the character's comment that she is from Minneapolis, and the fact that when the audience first sees her, she is exiting the school with a classroom of children."]
